name: Carotid Fibromuscular Dysplasia
description: Carotid and vertebral artery fibromuscular dysplasia is the second most common manifestation of FMD, affecting 25-30% of patients. It can present with stroke, transient ischemic attack, dissection, or be discovered incidentally. The internal carotid artery is typically affected in its mid to distal cervical segment. Unlike renal FMD, intervention is less straightforward, and management is often medical with antiplatelet therapy. Screening for intracranial aneurysms is essential due to the 12-14% association.

code.name: Occlusion and stenosis of unspecified carotid artery

statement.text: Carotid fibromuscular dysplasia affects 25-30% of FMD patients, presenting with stroke/TIA, dissection, or pulsatile tinnitus, with 12-14% having associated intracranial aneurysms requiring mandatory brain MRA screening.
statement.formal: Carotid FMD: Stroke/TIA + Dissection + Pulsatile Tinnitus → Mid-Distal Cervical ICA → MUST Screen for Intracranial Aneurysms (12-14%) → Usually Medical Management

explanation.intuition: A young person hearing their heartbeat in their ear (pulsatile tinnitus), having a stroke, or experiencing neck pain with Horner syndrome may have FMD in their carotid arteries - and needs brain imaging to check for associated aneurysms.
explanation.key_insight: The critical teaching point is that 12-14% of cerebrovascular FMD patients have intracranial aneurysms. Missing these could be fatal. Every patient with cervical FMD needs brain MRA screening for aneurysms.
explanation.technical_details: Cervical FMD affects the mid-to-distal internal carotid artery (at C1-C2 level), sparing the carotid bulb (unlike atherosclerosis). Management is usually medical with antiplatelet therapy. Intervention is reserved for recurrent symptoms despite medical therapy. Dissection is managed with anticoagulation or antiplatelet therapy.

epidemiology.frequency_in_fmd: 25-30% of FMD patients have cerebrovascular involvement

demographics.sex: Similar female predominance as renal FMD

epidemiology.location_in_vessel: Mid to distal cervical ICA (C1-C2 level), spares carotid bulb

presentation: Stroke or TIA in young patient
diagnosis: CTA or MRA from aortic arch to vertex
Brain MRA for intracranial aneurysm screening (12-14%)

asymptomatic.context: Imaging for other reasons, screening of FMD patient

stroke_tia.demographics: Important cause of stroke in young patients

dissection.mechanism: Inherently abnormal arterial wall predisposes to dissection

pulsatile_tinnitus.significance: Characteristic symptom - should prompt FMD evaluation

intracranial_aneurysm.mechanism: Associated arteriopathy, not direct extension of FMD
intracranial_aneurysm.importance: MUST screen for - risk of subarachnoid hemorrhage

findings: String of beads in mid-to-distal cervical ICA
cta_mra.coverage: Include intracranial circulation for aneurysm screening

duplex_ultrasound.limitation: Cannot visualize high cervical or intracranial

string_of_beads.appearance: Same as renal - beads larger than normal lumen in medial fibroplasia

intracranial_aneurysms.screening: MRA or CTA of brain recommended at baseline

renal_fmd.frequency: 30-40% of cervical FMD patients also have renal FMD

associated_conditions.other_vascular_beds: Complete vascular imaging (head to pelvis) should be considered

stroke_risk.with_dissection: Higher, depends on degree and management

anticoagulation_vs_antiplatelet.controversy: No clear RCT evidence for superiority
anticoagulation_vs_antiplatelet.approach: Anticoagulation (heparin then warfarin) or antiplatelet both acceptable

management_of_dissection.intervention: Rarely needed unless progressive despite medical therapy

technique.angioplasty: May be performed similar to renal
technique.stenting: Sometimes used for dissection or refractory stenosis

endovascular_treatment.outcomes: Variable, less established than renal FMD

fmd.appearance: String of beads or focal irregularity

stable_fmd.complete_imaging: Periodically to assess other vascular beds

surveillance.intracranial: Repeat MRA per neurosurgical recommendations if aneurysm present

clinical_pearls: Pulsatile tinnitus in young patient = think carotid FMD
12-14% have intracranial aneurysms - ALWAYS screen with brain MRA
Cervical FMD is a significant cause of carotid dissection in young patients
Medical management with antiplatelet therapy is first-line for most
learning_objectives: Identify clinical presentations of carotid fibromuscular dysplasia
Explain the importance of intracranial aneurysm screening in cerebrovascular FMD
Compare management approaches for carotid FMD versus atherosclerotic carotid disease

related.relationship: Most common FMD manifestation, often coexists
